factoid: Pierre wondered how Prince Andrew could talk like that.
Pierre considered Prince Andrew a model of perfection.
Prince Andrew possessed qualities that Pierre lacked, described as strength of will.
Prince Andrew had a calm manner of treating everybody.
Prince Andrew had extraordinary memory.
Prince Andrew had extensive reading.
Prince Andrew had read everything.
Prince Andrew knew everything.
Prince Andrew had an opinion about everything.
Prince Andrew had capacity for work and study.
Prince Andrew lacked capacity for philosophical meditation.
Pierre regarded Prince Andrew’s lack of philosophical meditation as a sign of strength.
Praise and commendation are essential in best, friendly, simplest relations of life.
Praise and commendation are like grease necessary to wheels for smooth running.
Prince Andrew said "My part is played out."
Prince Andrew said "What’s the use of talking about me? Let us talk about you."
Prince Andrew smiled at his reassuring thoughts.
Prince Andrew’s smile was reflected on Pierre’s face.
Pierre said "But what is there to say about me?"
Pierre said "What am I? An illegitimate son!"
Pierre blushed crimson.
Pierre made a great effort to say this.
Pierre said "Without a name and without means... And it really..."
Pierre did not say what "it really" was.
Pierre said "For the present I am free and am all right."
Pierre said "Only I haven’t the least idea what I am to do; I wanted to consult you seriously."
Prince Andrew looked kindly at Pierre.
Prince Andrew’s glance was friendly and affectionate.
Prince Andrew expressed a sense of his own superiority.
Prince Andrew said "I am fond of you, especially as you are the one live man among our whole set."
Prince Andrew said "Yes, you’re all right! Choose what you will; it’s all the same. You’ll be all right anywhere."
Prince Andrew told Pierre to give up visiting Kurágins and leading that sort of life, saying it suits him badly.
Prince Andrew asked "What would you have, my dear fellow?"
Pierre answered "Women, my dear fellow; women!"
Prince Andrew replied "I don’t understand it."
Prince Andrew said "Women who are comme il faut, that’s a different matter; but the Kurágins’ set of women, ‘women and wine’ I don’t understand!"
Pierre was staying at Prince Vasíli Kurágin’s and sharing the dissipated life of Prince Vasíli Kurágin’s son Anatole.
They planned to reform Anatole by marrying him to Prince Andrew’s sister.

Pierre said "Do you know? Seriously, I have long been thinking of it.... Leading such a life I can’t decide or think properly about anything. One’s head aches, and one spends all one’s money. He asked me for tonight, but I won’t go."
Pierre asked "You give me your word of honor not to go?"
Pierre replied "On my honor!"
It was past one o’clock when Pierre left Prince Andrew.
The night was cloudless, northern, and summer.
Pierre took an open cab intending to drive straight home.
As Pierre approached his house, he felt the impossibility of going to sleep on that night.
The light was enough to see a long way in the deserted street, and it seemed more like morning or evening than night.
On the way Pierre remembered that Anatole Kurágin was expecting the usual set for cards that evening, followed by a drinking bout, finishing with visits of a kind Pierre was fond of.
Pierre thought "I should like to go to Kurágin’s."
Pierre recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to go to Kurágin’s.
Pierre desired to enjoy dissipation he was accustomed to.
Pierre decided to go to Kurágin’s.
Pierre thought his promise to Prince Andrew was of no account because he had already promised Prince Anatole to come to his gathering.

Pierre thought "all such ‘words of honor’ are conventional things with no definite meaning, especially if one considers that by tomorrow one may be dead, or something extraordinary may happen to one that honor and dishonor will be all the same!"
Pierre often indulged in reflections that nullified all his decisions and intentions.
Pierre went to Kurágin’s.
